name: Stunning shadow fist (stunner monk build concept)
author: samurainostalgique

posts.author: samurainostalgique
posts.content:

He can come out of stealth and deliver 3 DC 40 stunning fists in the blink of an eye, and HIPS away if it doesn't work the first time.

Note that he will have XP penalities from level 17 onwards. However the alternatives are changing fighter to CoT (bad idea for this build in my opinion, as he will have very low damage without WS and EWS), or changing the race to human or dwarf, which means either dropping 1 point of AB because of the lower dexterity (I don't like this option as the build only has the standard 40 AB as it is, though unarmed monk attack progression helps with that), or spending two more epic feats on stat increases, thus lowering the stunning fist DC to 36, which kinda defeats the point of being a stunner monk in my opinion.

I wish I could squeeze more improved stunning fist feats into it, to get to a really ridiculous DC, however I'd have to either get more fighter levels, dropping important class features from monk and/or SD, start with a higher dexterity or wisdom, nerfing my strength and constitution to death in the process, or accept a lower AB (but you do need to hit your target for the stunning fist DC to even matter...). I'm wondering about how a totally dedicated stunner build like a Monk/fighter/CoT would fare. Such a build would lose HIPS, epic dodge and uncanny dodge, but would be able to spend 4 more feats on improved stunning fist, for a DC of 48...

posts.author: Theophilus Fist
posts.content: By Level 40, aren't most opponents immune to stun?

posts.author: hunearo
posts.content:
I would drop one improved stunning fist to get one more point in wisdom. Stun DC will drop by one, but you get one more ac and will save, imho it is a good trade.
If you go CoT14 you can take one more improved stunning fist instead of the weapon specializations.

Edit: or you can go monk25/cot10 and get the same amount of feats... More uses of stunning fists, but lower saves.

Edit: nope, I miscalculated the number of feats... With 14cot/21mnk or 10cot/25mnk you get the same number of feats as with 14ftr/21mnk (of course without specializations)

posts.author: samurainostalgique
posts.content:
Only immunity to critical hits protects against stunning fist. So against undeads and constructs, it is useless, but the same can be said about a rogue's sneak attacks or a WM's critical hits.

Since this build has perfect self, boosting will saves is not that appealing, so the real draw to an increased wisdom is the AC.
In fact, I did consider doing what you suggest hunearo, and even thought about dropping another improved stunning fist for armor skin, but doing this would mean I end up with just one improved stunning fist feat, and a DC of 37, which is not that great against melee (for me, the appeal of a stunner build is to be able to use SF effectively against any type of opponent that isn't immune to it). So at that point I would question even going for improved SF in the first place, considering it's costing me two points of AB (I could easily go for 34 DEX without it).

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Why not use Improved Knockdown instead? You get it for free at Monk 6. Undead aren't immune to that. I've played several Monks, but never bothered with Stunning Fist. Am I missing out?

posts.author: samurainostalgique
posts.content:
Improved knockdown is good, but not nearly as good as a very high DC stunning fist in my opinion (well, except when facing crit immune foes of course), for several reasons:

1. Knockdown only lasts one round, vs 3 for stunning fist
2. As a monk, you're likely to have lowish AB, which makes it difficult to use KD successfully on anything that has a good discipline, whereas with improved stunning fist feats, you can achieve such high DCs that even meleers will have trouble making the save
3. Speaking of AB, KD gives you a -4 penalty, whereas for a monk, SF has no penalty (if using a non-monk build though, you do get a -4 penalty, and it could be argued that going for improved SF worsens your AB since you need 19 wisdom for it, and you're investing epic feats in it, which could be spent into Great Dex instead)
4. You can't knockdown an already knocked down target to reset the duration of the prone status, whereas you can use stunning fist on an already stunned opponent to reset the duration of the stun, making it possible to stunlock tough opponents to death.

But of course, the limited uses per day, and the fact that it doesn't work against crit immune opponents are big limitations.
Personnally, I find it best to use SF either from stealth or on a knocked down opponent (well, on a flatfooted opponent really). Since you only have a limited amount of SF per day, it's better to make sure that they have as much chance of landing as possible by denying your opponent his dodge AC bonuses.

I do realize though that dedicated stunner builds are pretty rare in PvM, probably for good reasons. You do sacrifice a lot to get that high DC stunning fist. And you have to be dex based since ISF has 19 DEX as requirement, so, without sneak attack, it can be difficult to actually finish off stunned foes.

That shadowboxer build does seem like it could be quite effective in PVP, though I'd still play something a bit more versatile instead. But I appreciate it.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Monk 20/ Fighter 10/ CoT 10, would get you that DC of 48 (54) on stunning fist with Fort 31/ Ref 36/ Will 29 saves & 400 Hit Points. Pre-epic you could take Improved Power Attack to compensate for the lack of strength (instead of dodge/mobility) and the D20 punches would help in that regard. But you would, of course, lose the extra safety of HiPS/ Epic Dodge, although with a 70+ AC in a standard +5 environment & the famous Monk Speed you can mitigate the risks. That's about all you could do really, either go with your initial build or this one or even the one I tried long ago they all have the same stats/ potential in the end. It is not bad, not at all, but it isn't spectacular either, unfortunately, some builds have it far easier since dev. crit is so good relatively to the other paths one can go. Stunner Monks & Deathdealer Assassins shine a lot more in environments where the aforementioned feat is banned.

It depends on how many dev-crit enemies there are...If they are a frequent occurrence then I would prioritize safety first, it is only logical.

If however they are few and far between and you know how to deal with them, then going full-force would be my choice!
